occurrences.line_text: The cause of all this euill, who was slaine
Thought therewithall forthwith him to haue slaine,
Who when on ground they saw their fellow slaine,
As if they would haue slaine them presently.
Hast slaine my men in this vnmanly maner,
By this quite slaine in so vnequall fight:
With slaughtred bodies, which his hand had slaine,
Where he himselfe might see his foeman slaine;
And sib to great Orgolio, which was slaine
Else had he surely there bene slaine, or fowlyshent.
That slaine he was, or made a wretched thrall,
Slay not that Carle, though worthy to be slaine:
VVhilest Melibee is slaine:
Old Meliboe is slaine, and him beside
He at the length was slaine, and layd on ground,
How many of their friends were slaine, how many fone.
Were by them slaine by generall consent;
When she was slaine, or had bene to her succour nere.
Of Pastorell, were she aliue or slaine.
And sluggish german doest thy forces slake,
And slake the heauenly fire, that raged euermore.
Ne euer will their feruent fury slake,
To slake your wrath, and mollifie your mind,
Ne slake the furie of her cruell flame,
Them bound till his returne, their labour not to slake.
Ah but will heauens fury neuer slake,
Yet all that might not slake her sensuall desyre.
But sith the Sunne now ginnes to slake his beames,
Shewing desire her inward flame to slake:
In straunge disguize, to slake his scalding smart;
None but a God or godlike man can slake;
That she his fury willed him to slake:
How euer loth he were his way to slake,
Their forces furie, and their terror slake;
As they had potshares bene; for nought mote slake
At last when feruent sorrow slaked was,
So when they slaked had the feruent heat
Tho when they had their hunger slaked well,
The sandy Slane, the stony Aubrian,
Hewing and slashing at their idle shades;
Hewing, and slashing shields, and helmets bright,
So hard it is to be a womans slaue.
And as she spake, therewith she slauered;
For slaues to sell them, for no small reward,
T'inquire for slaues; where being readie met
And willed streight the slaues should forth be called,
From slaughter of the Giaunts conquered;
By chaunce beheld, he left the bloudy slaughter,
There then a piteous slaughter did begin:
Sought onely slaughter and auengement:
Commaunded him from slaughter to recoyle,
And glad he was the slaughter so to stay,
To stay their cruell hands from slaughter fell.
And tell him that not for such slaughters sake
Of slaughtred carkasses, her heart did quake
He slaughtred had, and ere they were halfe ded,
With slaughtred bodies, which his hand had slaine,
That shamefull Hag, the slaunder of her sexe,
Slaunderous reproches, and fowle infamies,
How to depraue, or slaunderously vpbrayd,
The Conquerour nought cared him to slay,
Corineus conquered, and cruelly did slay.
Of hardy Nennius, whom he yet did slay,
For perdie one shall other slay, or daunt:
But him shall slay, and on a gallowes bleake
And secretly his enemies did slay:
That th'heapes of those, which he did wound and slay,
They slay the Soudan, driue his wife
Her person, and her sacred selfe to slay:
Of that proud Souldan, whom he earst did slay.
And as he pressed in, him there did slay:
Doth slay the Monster, and restore
To saue her selfe, least that he did her slay:
Cryde out, Ah mercie Sir, doe me not slay,
Calidore sees young Tristram slay
That this was he, whom Tristram earst did slay,
Regarding neither speare, that mote him slay,
Did slay againe, as ye may see there in the stound.
Slay not that Carle, though worthy to be slaine:
Till I haue sau'd so many, as I earst did slay.
Whether to slay her there vpon the place,
To slay her on. And now the Euentyde
A further purpose, would not so them slay,
And all that nere him came, did hew and slay,
Should know thereof, to slay he would haue sought,
The crowned often slaine, the slayer cround,
Who slayes the Gyant, wounds the beast,
he slayes in Belges right.
Slaying Traherne, and hauing ouercome
And shamefull treason, who through guile hath slayn
Slayne of that errant knight, with whom he fought;
With his great yron sledge doth strongly on it beat.
And on his shield like yron sledges bet:
Here Sleep, there Richesse, & Hel-gate the[m] both betwext.
Sweet slo[m]bring deaw, the which to sleepe them biddes.
Where when all drownd in deadly sleepe he findes,
Who oft is wont to trouble gentle Sleepe.
Lets me not sleepe, but wast the wearie night
Whiles you in carelesse sleepe are drowned quight.
Hauing yrockt a sleepe his irkesome spright,
That here wex old in sleepe, whiles wicked wights
When euery creature shrowded is in sleepe;
And all in deadly sleepe did drowned lie,
Still drownd in sleepe, and most of his dayes ded;
Did chace away sweet sleepe from sluggish eye,
Lo where the stout Sansioy doth sleepe in deadly shade.
From loftie steed, and downe to sleepe me layd;
And layes the soule to sleepe in quiet graue?
Sleepe after toyle, port after stormie seas,
Thou doest awake, sleepe neuer he so sownd,
And slyding soft, as downe to sleepe her layd,
And bid them sleepe in euerlasting peace.
Of kindly sleepe, that did them ouertake.
To lull him soft a sleepe, that by it lay;
Sometimes he falsely faines himselfe to sleepe,
By this she had him lulled fast a sleepe,
In slouthfull sleepe his molten hart to steme,
Ne would he suffer Sleepe once thither-ward
For next to death is Sleepe to be compard:
Or euer sleepe his eye-strings did vntye,
For want of food, and sleepe, which two vpbeare,
Suffers her selfe through sleepe beguild to bee,
Yet liues his memorie, though carcas sleepe in rest.
Where him to sleepe she gently would perswade,
Was drowned in the depth of deadly sleepe,
She with her Nourse adowne to sleepe did lye;
But sleepe full farre away from her did fly:
In her warme bed to sleepe, if that she might;
So that at last a little creeping sleepe
Or doen they onely sleepe, and shall againe reuerse?
But if they sleepe, ï¿½ let them soone awake:
Finding the Nymph a sleepe in secret wheare,
Vpon the grassie ground, to sleepe a throw;
But gentle Sleepe enuyde him any rest;
The beautie of his worke? Indeed in sleepe
In stead of sleepe thou sendest troublous feares,
To sleepe, the whiles a gentle slombring swowne
There a sad cloud of sleepe her ouerkest,
Who in her sleepe (a wondrous thing to say)
Ne did she let dull sleepe once to relent,
He vs'd to slug, or sleepe in slothfull shade:
But all the while the fisher did securely sleepe.
To shrowd themselues, whiles sleepe their senses did inuade.
At night, when all they went to sleepe, he vewd,
When wearie of their sport to sleepe they fell,
That he dare neuer sleepe, but that one eye
Or doth thy iustice sleepe, and silent ly?
Of secret daunger, ne let sleepe oppresse
In silence and in sleepe themselues did shroud,
I saw him sleepe with her all night his fill,
doth sleepe from him expell.
When gentle sleepe his heauie eyes would close;
And euermore, when he to sleepe did thinke,
Ne suffred sleepe to settle in his brest.
So oftentimes he out of sleepe abrayd,
Yet in his soundest sleepe, his dayly feare
Where fearelesse I to sleepe me downe did lay.
But when as I did out of sleepe abray,
There heauie sleepe the eye-lids did surprise
Ne dayly food did take, ne nightly sleepe,
Like as a wayward childe, whose sounder sleepe
Not suffering the least twinckling sleepe to start
Vnto your losse: and now needes will ye sleepe?
Now will ye sleepe? ah wake, and rather weepe,
Ne lesse did Talus suffer sleepe to seaze
Ne suffred slothfull sleepe her eyelids to oppresse.
Of sencelesse sleepe did deeply drowned lie,
That vnder Isis feete doth sleepe for euer:
Bad doe away the dampe of drouzie sleepe,
Could sleepe all night, that in vnquiet brest
Ne day nor night did sleepe, t'attend them on,
Did sleepe all night through weary trauell of his quest.
Would to no bed, nor take no kindely sleepe,
And layd her vnderneath a bush to sleepe,
To seeke, if he perchance a sleepe were layd,
Possessed of sweete sleepe, that luld him soft in swound.
Now drowned in the depth of sleepe all fearelesse lay.
Or suffer her out of her sleepe to wake,
Sleepe out her fill, without encomberment:
For sleepe they sayd would make her battill better.
But all the night in siluer sleepe I spend,
A fit false dreame, that can delude the sleepers sent.
That when he sleepes in most security,
In louely wise, and sleepes, and sports, and playes;
Perceiu'd my thought, and drownd in sleepie night,
Whose sleepie head she in her lap did soft dispose.
Who thereat wondrous wroth, the sleeping spark
Deare Dame (quoth he) you sleeping sparkes awake,
Where sleeping late she left her other knight.
Dead sleeping Poppy, and blacke Hellebore,
And enuie base, to barke at sleeping fame:
As to doen outrage to a sleeping ghost:
Her other sonne fast sleeping did oppresse,
The young man sleeping by her, seemd to bee
Yet sleeping, in his well proportiond face,
Of sleeping praise, were hong vpon a tree,
Which shall reuiue the sleeping memorie
That her in daffadillies sleeping made,
Would afterwards afresh the sleeping euill reare.
There where through weary trauel she lay sleeping sou[n]d.
With that the Crocodile, which sleeping lay
For shame he weend a sleeping wight to wound.
Whylest time did offer meanes him sleeping to surprize.
Backe to the place, whereas his Lord he sleeping vew'd.
Lay sleeping soundly in the bushes shade,
He seekes out mighty charmes, to trouble sleepy mindes
First rings his siluer Bell t'each sleepy wight,
At length breakes downe in raine, and haile, and sleet,
And sleeues dependant Albanese-wyse:
Would safe depart, for all his subtill sleight,
And well perceiued his deceiptfull sleight,
And through his nimble sleight did vnder him down cast.
Which subtill sleight did him encumber much,
Did cast about by sleight the truth thereout to straine.
And some by sleight he eke doth vnderfong.
T'enquire of them, whether by force, or sleight,
Then he by cunning sleights in at the window crept.
At last by subtill sleights she him betraid
her false sleights doe imploy.
With thousand other sleights: for well he kend,
In cunning sleights and practick knauery.
Tryde all her arts, & all her sleights, thence out to wrest.
Then with what sleights and sweet allurements she
And all the sleights vnbosomd in his hart;
Where force might not auaile, their sleights and art
But couered with a slender veile afore;
Yet but a slender slip, that scarse did see
Cast to requite, and with a slender dart,
There as thou slepst in tender swadling band,
Whose prayses hauing slept in silence long,
So sound he slept, that nought mought him awake.
Where he slept soundly void of euill thought,
Still when she slept, he kept both watch and ward,
He did disrobe, when all men carelesse slept,
Whiles old Syluanus slept in shady arber sownd.
And whilst he slept, she ouer him would spred
She soundly slept, & carefull thoughts did quite assoile.
Whether she slept or wakt, with her soft hand
Hath long time slept, himselfe so shall he shake,
In which there slept a fisher old and pore,
And to his wife, that now full soundly slept,
She slept, yet twixt her eyelids closely spyde,
Till feeling life to fayle, it fell, and deadly slept.
Ere he had slept his fill, he wakened were,
In which his loue was lost, he slept full fast,
After a late forray, and slept full sound,
Of him, that slew Sansfoy with bloudie knife;
Entrapped slew, and brought to shamefull graue.
And how he slew with glauncing dart amisse
That Redcrosse knight, perdie, I neuer slew,
Which great Alcides in Stremona slew,
With wrathfull hand I slew her innocent;
The one she slew in that impatient stoure,
Which hight of him Glamorgan, there him slew:
And Ymner slew, or Logris miscreate;
Rather then fly, or be captiu'd her selfe she slew.
But him Allectus treacherously slew,
Soone after which, three hundred Lordes he slew
Whom with his brethren Timias slew, befell:
And slew him cruelly, ere any reskew came.
The Palfrey, whereon she did trauell, slew,
Slew cruelly, and in the riuer drowned quight.
A cruell carle, the which all strangers slew,
Him selfe to saue: but he there slew him at the skreene.
Did enter in, and slew the Porter on the flore.
This knight, whom Tristram slew, had wounded sore
(Whom Tristram slew) them in that shadow found,
So miserably him all helpelesse slew,
Saued him selfe, but that he there him slew:
Encountring him with small resistance slew;
Still slew the formost, that came first to hand,
Vnder Slewbloome in shady groue was got,
Strong Allo tombling from Slewlogher steep,
Whiles on his broad round backe they softly slid
And next to him the Nene downe softly slid;
His nigh forwearied feeble feet did slide,
Who suffred not his wandring feet to slide.
Eftsoones her shallow ship away did slide,
And they with aire, that not a drop can slide:
In th'other scale; but still it downe did slide,
The morish Cole, and the soft sliding Breane,
Who meeting earst with Archimago slie,
But with slie shiftes and wiles did vnderminde
By subtile engins and malitious slight
By subtilty, nor slight, nor might, nor mighty charme.
That he descride, and shonned still his slight:
With such faire slight him Guyon often faild,
False faitour Scudamour, that hast by slight
Was so expert in euery subtile slight,
Where fast infixed, whilest he sought by slight
She gaue vnto him, gotten by her slight
Whether by might extort, or else by slight deceaued.
Of Guizor, by thee slaine, and murdred by thy slight.
Least by such slight he were vnwares deceiued;
Like fruitlesse braunches, which the hatchets slight
So also did this Monster vse like slight
By guilefull treason and by subtill slight
He can deuize this counter-cast of slight,
To ouerthrow, but to supplant by slight.
For to maligne, t'enuie, t'vse shifting slight,
In yuory sheath, ycaru'd with curious slights;
He them abused, through his subtill slights,
Through these his slights he many doth confound,
For he in slights and iugling feates did flow,
Warning him hold it fast, for feare of slights.
Whom they by slights allur'd, and to their purpose lad.
His fattie waues do fertile slime outwell,
Brought forth this monstrous masse of earthly slime,
But of thing like to that ï¿½/-gyptian slime,
All were they borne of her owne natiue slime,
What time th'eternall Lord in fleshly slime
Had she not bene deuoyd of mortall slime,
That is ingenerate in fleshly slime.
I gan refraine, in minde to slip away,
Else she will slip away, and all our drift despise.
Yet but a slender slip, that scarse did see
When his foote slipt (that slip he dearely rewd,)
Through slipperie footing, fell into the brooke,
Whose doome was death, but lightly slipping by,
He slips aside; the whiles that furious beast
When his foote slipt (that slip he dearely rewd,)
And comming where the knight in slomber lay,
Whiles creeping slomber made him to forget
My senses lulled are in slomber of delight.
Out of her quiet slomber did awake,
That doth the charmed Snake in slomber lay:
Out of his quiet slomber him abrade,
His slomber, yet so mazed, that he nothing spake.
Vpon the ground a while in slomber lay;
On him, the which his quiet slomber brake:
Soft rombling brookes, that gentle slomber drew;
The whyles his Lord in siluer slomber lay,
There she had him now layd a slombering,
Then vp he tooke the slombred sencelesse corse,
Keeping that slombred corse to him assynd;
Sweet slo[m]bring deaw, the which to sleepe them biddes.
In slombring swownd nigh voyd of vitall spright,
And slombring soft my hart did steale away,
As one awakt out of long slombring shade,
And if that any drop of slombring rest
To sleepe, the whiles a gentle slombring swowne
As if he had bene slombring in the shade,
Faire Crysogone in slombry traunce whilere:
To banish sloth, that oft doth noble mindes annoy.
He vs'd to slug, or sleepe in slothfull shade:
Ne suffred slothfull sleepe her eyelids to oppresse.
Theseus condemned to endlesse slouth by law,
To slug in slouth and sensuall delights,
And in lewd slouth to wast his carelesse day:
Of falshood or of slouth, when most it may behoue.
If he for slouth forslackt so famous quest.
Vpon a slouthfull Asse he chose to ryde,
The slouthfull waue of that great griesly lake;
In slouthfull sleepe his molten hart to steme,
The slouthfull bodie, that doth loue to steepe
And heauie sat vpon her palfrey slow:
As her slow beast could make; but all in vaine:
A damzell spyde slow footing her before,
Abessa daughter of Corceca slow,
Ere long he came, where Vna traueild slow,
Thenceforth her waters waxed dull and slow,
With lookes full lowly cast, and gate full slow,
And euer with slow pace the knight did lead,
Sore bruzed with the fall, he slow vprose,
Tempring the passion with aduizement slow,
Or whether swift I wend, or whether slow:
Both slow and swift a like do serue my tourne,
The waues thereof so slow and sluggish were,
And his slow eyes beguiled of their sight,
Where by the grim floud of Cocytus slow
Which Cambell seeing come, was nothing slow
She drew her far, and led with slow delay.
Slow Peneus, and tempestuous Phasides,
So oft as Slowth still in the mire did stand.
Which doen, the Chamberlain Slowth did to rest them call.
To slug in slouth and sensuall delights,
He vs'd to slug, or sleepe in slothfull shade:
Was sluggish Idlenesse the nourse of sin;
Did chace away sweet sleepe from sluggish eye,
And sluggish german doest thy forces slake,
Nor timely tides did driue out of their sluggish sourse.
The waues thereof so slow and sluggish were,
In his free thought to build her sluggish nest:
Lo sluggish Knight the victors happie pray:
And more, to lulle him in his slumber soft,
And by the altars side her selfe to slumber plaste.
Where soone he slumbred, fearing not be harm'd,
There the good Guyon he found slumbring fast
Full of the makers guile, with vsage sly
The Prince, with patience and sufferaunce sly
Couer'd with lids deuiz'd of substance sly,
And broke his staffe, with which he charmed semblants sly.
And entertaine with her occasions sly,
From hand to hand, and with such nimblesse sly
That they auoyded were, and vainely by did slyde.
Was with the force nigh feld whilst his right foot did slyde.
So sore, that tombling backe, he downe did slyde
So slyding softly forth, she turnd as to her ease.
And slyding soft, as downe to sleepe her layd,
Next him went Wylibourne with passage slye,
So slyly, that she did not feele the wound,
Began some smacke of comfort new to tast,
Of two smal grooms, which by their names were hight
Her fruitfull cursed spawne of serpents small,
Small drops of gory bloud, that trickled downe the same.
That in their cotage small, that night she rest her may.
Who streight him rent in thousand peeces small,
Then tooke that Squire an horne of bugle small,
There her small Gondelay her port did make,
But would they thinke, with how small allowaunce
That made him scorne all creatures great and small,
His single speare could doe him small redresse,
Their murmuring small trompets sounden wide,
Rowme in their writs; yet the same writing small
Ne ought ye want, but skill, which practize small
He liues, but takes small ioy of his renowne;
She pownded small, and did in peeces bruze,
As glad of that small rest, as Bird of tempest gon.
To get small thankes, and therewith many blames,
Ne in small meares containe his glory great,
That at the last he found a caue with entrance small.
And her small wast girt round with yron bands,
And that great brasen pillour broke in peeces small.
He had small lust to buy his loue so deare,
Is wicked discord, whose small sparkes once blowen
Great matter growing of beginning small;
They lightly her requit (for small delight
Which being brought, about her middle small
But to small purpose yron wedges made;
Whereto thus Scudamour, Small harme it were
He part of his small feast to her would share;
Where one stood peeping through a creuis small,
Contayned be, and in small compasse hild?
The Churne, and Charwell, two small streames, which   pained
And Albany: And Eden though but small,
Ill can he rule the great, that cannot reach the small.
But like a little Mount of small degree;
That all his bones, as small as sandy grayle
Such loathly matter were small lust to speake, or thinke.
Like as a flowre, whose silken leaues small,
As he had vow'd, some small continuaunce
Glad of that easement, though it were but small;
Small praise to proue your powre on wight so weake.
Small was his house, and like a little cage,
With small adoe, and nature satisfyde,
That hauing small, yet doe I not complaine
In this small plot of your dominion,
I may here with your selfe some small repose obtaine.
For slaues to sell them, for no small reward,
Some shew of fauour, by him gracing small,
But when she saw, through that small fauours gaine,
Encountring him with small resistance slew;
Whose smallest minute lost, no riches render may.
Ne let vaine feares procure your needlesse smart,
Oft tempred is (quoth she) with muchell smart:
Leaue off their worke, vnmindfull of their smart,
Tho gathering vp the relicks of his smart
The saluage nation feele her secret smart,
That launched hath my brest with bleeding smart.
And counsell mittigates the greatest smart;
Who all enrag'd with smart and franticke yre,
At last resolu'd to worke his finall smart,
The which doth quench the brond of hellish smart,
And came to Coelia to declare her smart,
That with the vncouth smart the Monster lowdly cryde.
With heat, toyle, wounds, armes, smart, & inward fire
Then of the grieuous smart, which him did wring,
Pittifull spectacle of deadly smart,
Of ruefull pitie, and impatient smart,
And tell the secret of your mortall smart;
The strong through pleasure soonest falles, the weake through smart.
She last should smart: with which cruell intent,
Therewith to doen his foes eternall smart.
With hope of thing, that may allegge his smart;
Tho gan she to renew her former smart,
My stubborne smart, but more annoyance breed,
My raging smart, ne ought my flame relent,
And thought so to beguile her grieuous smart;
But so her smart was much more grieuous bred,
Full of soft passion and vnwonted smart:
Or long enlargement of her painefull smart.
Then still the smart thereof increased more,
Was neuer better time to shew thy smart,
Croscuts the liuer with internall smart,
And feed it selfe with selfe-consuming smart?
In straunge disguize, to slake his scalding smart;
Yet was thy loue her death, & her death was thy smart.
In wilfull languor and consuming smart,
Ah who can loue the worker of her smart?
Seuen moneths he so her kept in bitter smart,
The beast astonisht stands in middest of his smart.
Smart daunts not mighty harts, but makes them more to swell.
And pacifie the strife, which causd so deadly smart.
Yet did the smart remaine, though he himselfe did flee.
And nourisheth her owne consuming smart?
Thou martyrest with sorow and with smart,
That she gan mone his vndeserued smart,
For like the stings of Aspes, that kill with smart,
Besought her to graunt ease vnto my smart,
Would quite haue burst through great abundance of her smart.
